sn5.3:4.2: Then the nun Kisāgotamī got dressed in the morning and, taking her bowl and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
sn5.3:4.3: She wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on her return from alms-round, she went to the Blind Man’s Wood,
sn5.3:4.4: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
sn5.3:4.5: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Kisāgotamī feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from convergence,
sn5.3:4.6: went up to her and addressed her in verse:
sn5.3:5.1: “Why do you sit alone and cry
sn5.3:5.2: as if your children have died?
sn5.3:5.3: You’ve come to the woods all alone—
sn5.3:5.4: you must be looking for a man!”
sn5.3:6.2: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
sn5.3:6.4: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from convergence!”
sn5.3:7.1: Then Kisāgotamī, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn5.3:8.1: “I’ve got over the death of children,
sn5.3:8.4: and I’m not afraid of you, sir!
sn5.3:9.1: Relishing is destroyed in every respect,
sn5.3:9.2: and the mass of darkness is shattered.
sn5.3:9.3: I’ve defeated the army of death,
sn5.3:10.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Kisāgotamī knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
